title: 108_s759
content: The Act is titled the "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or the "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003." It introduces a credit for residential small wind energy systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures made by individuals. The credit is limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications. Unused credits can be carried forward to future years. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures allows for excess credits to be carried forward to future taxable years. Qualified wind energy property expenditure is defined as an expenditure for qualified wind energy property installed on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence, including installation fees. Qualified wind energy property refers to a qualifying wind turbine. Qualified wind energy property is defined as a qualifying wind turbine with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less, with a 5-year limited warranty for defects. The turbine must be installed by the taxpayer or have a warranty for installation if done by another party. Qualified wind energy property with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less must meet the latest performance standards and be used to generate electricity. Labor costs for onsite preparation, assembly, and installation, as well as expenses for interconnecting the property to the energy grid, are eligible for consideration. Expenditures related to energy storage mediums like swimming pools are also included. Expenditures for energy storage mediums like swimming pools are not considered for this section. Special rules apply for joint occupancy dwelling units, where individuals are treated as one taxpayer for the purpose of determining the allowable credit. The credit for energy expenditures is determined by treating individuals as one taxpayer for the calendar year. Each individual can claim a credit based on their proportion of total expenditures. Special rules apply for tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations. Tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations and members of condominium management associations are treated as having made their proportionate share of any expenditures of their respective entities for tax credit purposes. For tax credit purposes, tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations and members of condominium management associations are considered to have made their proportionate share of expenditures. If less than 80 percent of a qualified wind energy property is used for nonbusiness purposes and selling energy, only the portion of expenditures allocated to nonbusiness use is eligible. For tax credit purposes, expenditures for qualified wind energy property are allocated based on nonbusiness use and energy generation for sale to others. Expenditures are considered made when the property is installed and operational, except for construction-related expenses. Expenditures for qualified wind energy property are treated as made when the original use of the structure begins. The amount of any expenditure is the cost thereof. Expenditures made from subsidized energy financing are not taken into account. Basis adjustments are made if a credit is allowed for qualified wind energy property. The basis of qualified wind energy property is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. This section does not apply to property installed after December 31, 2008. The credit allowed for the taxable year cannot exceed the sum of the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55. The text discusses amendments to the tax code related to credits allowable for the taxable year, specifically in relation to the regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55. Amendments are made to sections 25C, 23, and 24 of the tax code. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code, including inserting "and section 25C" after "this section" in section 24(b)(3)(B) and making changes to sections 25, 25B, and 25C in other sections. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code, including adding section 25C and making changes to sections 23, 25, and 1400C. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code, including adding section 25C and making changes to section 1400C(d) by inserting "and section 25C" after "this section". Section 25C applies to residential wind energy property, with amendments effective for expenditures after December 31, 2002. Subsection (b) amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a credit is provided for business installation of small wind energy property. The amendment to section 48 of the Internal Revenue Code defines qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009. Qualified wind energy property is a qualifying wind turbine installed on or in connection with a property. The qualifying wind turbine must be installed on a farm, ranch, or eligible small business in the United States, owned and used by the taxpayer, with the original use starting with the taxpayer, and carrying at least a 5-year limited warranty. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. A qualifying wind turbine must have a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts. The term 'qualifying wind turbine' refers to a wind turbine with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less that meets performance standards set by industry associations. Safety certifications are required for the wind energy property to qualify for a tax credit. The energy percentage for qualified wind energy property is 30 percent, and for other energy property, it is 10 percent. Section 29(b)(3)(A)(i)(III) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended. These amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2003.
